name.text: (not in quiz) 37.2.3.13 Five machines in a factory

questiontext.text:
Exercise

There are five machines in a factory. Of these machines, three are working properly and two are defective. Machines which are working properly produce articles each of which has independently a probability of {@p_no_def@} of being imperfect. For the defective machines, this probability is {@p_def@}. A machine is chosen at random and {@n_art@} articles produced by the machine are examined. What is the probability that the machine chosen is defective given that, of the {@n_art@} articles examined, {@n_imp@} are imperfect and {@n_perf@} are perfect?

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Note: please round your answer up to 5 decimal places

generalfeedback.text:
Let \(D\) denote the event that the chosen machine is defective and \(\bar{D}\) denote the event “not \(D\)”.

Let \(Y\) be the number of imperfect articles in the sample of five.

Then

\(\begin{aligned} \text{P}(D \mid Y={@n_art@}) & = \dfrac{ \text{P}(D)\times \text{P}(Y={@n_art@} \mid D)}{ \text{P}(D)\times \text{P}(Y={@n_art@} \mid D) + \text{P}(\bar{D})\times \text{P}(Y={@n_art@} \mid \bar{D})}  \\ & = \dfrac{ \dfrac{2}{5} \times \left( \begin{array}{c} {@n_art@} \\ {@n_imp@} \end{array} \right) \times {@p_def@}^{{@n_imp@}} \times {@1 - p_def@}^{{@n_perf@}}}{ \frac{2}{5} \times \left( \begin{array}{c} {@n_art@} \\ {@n_imp@} \end{array} \right) \times {@p_def@}^{{@n_imp@}} \times {@1 - p_def@}^{{@n_perf@}} + \dfrac{3}{5} \times \left( \begin{array}{c} {@n_art@} \\ {@n_imp@} \end{array} \right) {@p_no_def@}^{{@n_imp@}} \times {@1 - p_no_def@}^{{@n_perf@}}} \\  & =  \dfrac{{@decimalplaces(numerator,5)@}}{{@decimalplaces(denomin_1,5)@} + {@decimalplaces(denomin_2,5)@}} = {@ta@}.\end{aligned}\)

questionvariables.text: p_no_def: 0.1 + 0.1*rand(3) p_def: p_no_def + 0.1 n_art: 4 + rand(3) n_imp:1 + rand(2) n_perf:n_art - n_imp numerator: 0.4*(factorial(n_art)/(factorial(n_imp)*factorial(n_art-n_imp)))*(p_def^n_imp)*((1-p_def)^n_perf) denomin_1: numerator denomin_2: 0.6*(factorial(n_art)/(factorial(n_imp)*factorial(n_art-n_imp)))*(p_no_def^n_imp)*((1-p_no_def)^n_perf) ta: decimalplaces(numerator/(denomin_1 + denomin_2),5)
